canonical_explanation.text: An electric cell is a device that converts chemical energy into electrical energy. It has two terminals: a positive terminal (marked +) and a negative terminal (marked −). A battery is a combination of two or more cells. An electric circuit is a closed path through which electric current flows. Materials that allow electricity to pass through them are called conductors, while those that do not are called insulators. A switch is used to open or close a circuit.
rules: An electric cell has two terminals: positive (+) and negative (−).
A battery is a combination of two or more cells connected together.
An electric circuit is a complete, closed path for electric current to flow.
A closed circuit allows current to flow; an open circuit does not.
An electric switch is used to open or close a circuit.
Conductors are materials that allow electricity to pass through them (e.g., metals, water).
Insulators are materials that do not allow electricity to pass through them (e.g., rubber, plastic, wood).
In a circuit diagram, standard symbols are used for cell, battery, bulb, switch, and wire.
Electric current flows from the positive terminal to the negative terminal of a cell (conventional current).
A bulb glows only when the circuit is complete (closed).

questions.question_text: An electric cell has how many terminals?
questions.explanation_correct: An electric cell has two terminals — a positive terminal (+) and a negative terminal (−). The positive terminal is the metal cap and the negative terminal is the flat metal disc at the bottom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electric cell always has exactly two terminals: positive (+) and negative (−). It does not have one, three, or four terminals.

questions.question_text: What type of energy does an electric cell convert into electrical energy?
questions.explanation_correct: An electric cell contains chemicals that react to produce electricity. It converts chemical energy stored in the chemicals into electrical energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electric cell does not convert heat, light, or mechanical energy. The chemicals inside the cell undergo a reaction that produces electrical energy, so it converts chemical energy into electrical energy.

questions.question_text: A battery is made up of:

options.text: Two or more cells connected together

questions.explanation_correct: A battery is a combination of two or more cells connected together. For example, a torch may use two or three cells connected end to end, forming a battery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A single cell is just called a cell, not a battery. A battery specifically refers to two or more cells combined. It is not made of only wires, switches, or bulbs.

questions.question_text: The positive terminal of an electric cell is the small metal cap on top.
questions.explanation_correct: The metal cap (bump) on top of a dry cell is the positive terminal (+), and the flat metal disc at the bottom is the negative terminal (−).
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. In a standard dry cell, the raised metal cap on top is the positive terminal and the flat bottom is the negative terminal.

questions.question_text: An electric circuit is:

options.text: A closed path through which electric current flows
A wire connected to only one terminal of a cell

questions.explanation_correct: An electric circuit is a complete, closed path that allows electric current to flow from one terminal of a cell through the components (like a bulb) and back to the other terminal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electric circuit is not just any arrangement of wires — it must form a complete closed path. It is not a cell itself, and a wire connected to only one terminal does not form a circuit.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a component of a simple electric circuit?
questions.explanation_correct: A simple electric circuit consists of a cell (or battery), connecting wires, a bulb (or other device), and optionally a switch. A magnet is not a component of a basic electric circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electric cell provides energy, wires carry current, and a bulb uses the current. A magnet is not needed in a simple electric circuit and is not a circuit component.

questions.question_text: For a bulb to glow, the electric circuit must be ___ (open/closed).
questions.explanation_correct: A bulb glows only when the circuit is closed (complete). In a closed circuit, current flows from the cell through the wires and bulb and back to the cell, making the bulb glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'closed.' An open circuit has a break in the path, so current cannot flow and the bulb will not glow. Only a closed circuit allows current to flow.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a conductor of electricity?
questions.explanation_correct: Iron is a metal and all metals are good conductors of electricity. Conductors allow electric current to pass through them easily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rubber, plastic, and wood are all insulators — they do not allow electricity to pass through them. Iron is a metal and is a good conductor of electricity.

questions.question_text: Materials that do not allow electricity to pass through them are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Insulators are materials that do not allow electric current to pass through them. Examples include rubber, plastic, wood, and glass. They are used to protect us from electric shocks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conductors allow electricity to pass. Semiconductors partially allow it (not covered at this level). Magnets are related to magnetism, not electrical conduction. Insulators are the correct answer.

questions.question_text: All metals are conductors of electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: All metals are good conductors of electricity. Metals like copper, iron, aluminium, gold, and silver allow electric current to flow through them easily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. All metals are conductors of electricity. This is one of the common properties of metals.

questions.question_text: What is the function of an electric switch in a circuit?

options.text: To increase the brightness of the bulb
To open or close the circuit

questions.explanation_correct: An electric switch is a device used to open or close an electric circuit. When the switch is ON (closed), the circuit is complete and current flows. When the switch is OFF (open), the circuit is broken and current stops flowing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A switch does not increase brightness, produce electricity, or store electricity. Its function is simply to open (break) or close (complete) the circuit, controlling whether current flows or not.

questions.question_text: When a switch is in the OFF position, the circuit is:
questions.explanation_correct: When a switch is OFF, it creates a gap (break) in the circuit, making it an open circuit. In an open circuit, the path is broken and electric current cannot flow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A switch in the OFF position breaks the circuit, making it open. A closed circuit means current flows (switch ON). The switch OFF position creates an open circuit.

questions.question_text: A torch uses 3 cells. How many cells make up the battery in this torch?
questions.explanation_correct: A battery is a combination of two or more cells. If the torch uses 3 cells, then the battery consists of 3 cells connected together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The torch uses 3 cells connected together, and this combination of 3 cells forms the battery. The number of cells in the battery equals the number of cells used.

questions.question_text: Arun connected a cell, a bulb, and wires, but the bulb did not glow. Which of the following could be the reason?

options.text: The wire is disconnected at one point, leaving the circuit open

questions.explanation_correct: If the wire is disconnected at any point, the circuit is open (incomplete). In an open circuit, current cannot flow and the bulb will not glow. This is the most likely reason.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A complete circuit would make the bulb glow, so that is not the problem. A new cell and a new bulb should work properly. A disconnected wire breaks the circuit, preventing current flow.

questions.question_text: In an electric circuit, copper wires are used because copper is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Copper is used for electric wires because it is an excellent conductor of electricity. It allows electric current to flow through it very easily with minimal resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper is not an insulator or a magnetic material. While cost may be a factor, the main reason copper is used for wires is that it is one of the best conductors of electricity.

questions.question_text: Electric wires are covered with plastic or rubber coating. The reason for this is:

options.text: To prevent electric shock, as plastic and rubber are insulators

questions.explanation_correct: Plastic and rubber are insulators — they do not allow electricity to pass through. By covering metal wires with these insulating materials, we are protected from touching the live wire and getting an electric shock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The coating is not for appearance, strength, or better conductivity. The insulating cover of plastic or rubber prevents people from accidentally touching the conducting wire and getting an electric shock.

questions.question_text: Meena has a cell, a bulb, wires, and a switch. She connects all of them but forgets to turn the switch ON. Will the bulb glow?

options.text: Yes, because all components are connected
No, because the switch is OFF and the circuit is open

questions.explanation_correct: When the switch is OFF, it creates a break in the circuit, making it an open circuit. In an open circuit, current cannot flow, so the bulb will not glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Even though all components are connected, the switch being OFF means the circuit is open (broken). Current cannot flow through an open circuit, so the bulb will not glow at all.

questions.question_text: In a torch, when you slide the switch to the ON position, what happens inside?

options.text: The cell is removed from the torch
The circuit is completed and current flows, making the bulb glow
The bulb produces its own electricity

questions.explanation_correct: When you slide the switch to ON, a metal strip connects the circuit path, closing the circuit. Current flows from the cell through the wires to the bulb and back, making the bulb glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell stays in place. The bulb does not produce electricity — it receives it from the cell. Wires do not generate light. Turning the switch ON completes the circuit, allowing current to flow and the bulb to glow.

questions.question_text: A student tests different materials to check if they conduct electricity. She places each material between two wires in a circuit with a bulb. Which material will make the bulb glow?
questions.explanation_correct: An iron nail is made of metal (iron), which is a conductor of electricity. When placed in the circuit, it allows current to flow, completing the circuit and making the bulb glow. The other materials are insulators.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rubber (eraser), wood, and plastic are all insulators — they will not allow current to flow. Only the iron nail, being a metal conductor, will complete the circuit and make the bulb glow.

questions.question_text: What happens if a wire in a circuit is broken or cut?

options.text: The bulb stops glowing because the circuit becomes open

questions.explanation_correct: A broken or cut wire creates a gap in the circuit, making it an open circuit. In an open circuit, the path for current flow is broken, so current stops flowing and the bulb stops glowing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A broken wire does not make the bulb brighter or dimmer — it stops the current entirely. The circuit becomes open (incomplete), and the bulb stops glowing.

questions.question_text: If you connect the positive terminal of one cell to the positive terminal of another cell, the cells will work properly as a battery.
questions.explanation_correct: For cells to work properly as a battery, the positive terminal of one cell must be connected to the negative terminal of the next cell. Connecting positive to positive (or negative to negative) will not make the battery work correctly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. In a battery, cells must be connected in the correct order: the positive terminal of one cell to the negative terminal of the next. Connecting same terminals together does not produce a working battery.

questions.question_text: A simple switch can be made at home using:

options.text: Two rubber bands and a wooden board
A safety pin (metal) attached to a cardboard base with drawing pins

questions.explanation_correct: A simple switch can be made using a safety pin (conductor) attached to a cardboard base with metal drawing pins. When the safety pin touches both drawing pins, the circuit is closed (ON). When it is lifted, the circuit is open (OFF).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rubber bands, plastic sheets, paper, and glue are all insulators and cannot conduct electricity. A switch needs a conducting material (like a metal safety pin) that can be moved to open or close the circuit.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the best insulator?
questions.explanation_correct: Rubber is an excellent insulator — it does not allow electricity to pass through it. Silver, aluminium, and copper are all metals and are good conductors of electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silver, aluminium, and copper are all metals and excellent conductors of electricity. Rubber is the only insulator in the list and is the best insulator among the options.

questions.question_text: In a circuit diagram, a bulb is represented by a specific symbol. What does the circuit diagram help us do?

options.text: Represent the circuit using standard symbols that everyone can understand
Measure the brightness of the bulb

questions.explanation_correct: Circuit diagrams use standard symbols for components like cells, bulbs, switches, and wires. This allows anyone to understand the circuit easily, regardless of language, making communication about circuits universal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Circuit diagrams are not about drawing artistic pictures, measuring brightness, or counting electrons. They provide a standard, universal way to represent electric circuits using symbols.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: A cell can make a bulb glow.
Reason: A cell converts chemical energy into electrical energy.
Which of the following is correct?

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and the reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct, but the reason does not explain the assertion
The assertion is correct but the reason is incorrect
Both assertion and reason are incorrect

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is correct — a cell can make a bulb glow (when connected in a circuit). The reason is also correct — a cell converts chemical energy into electrical energy. The reason explains the assertion because it is this electrical energy that powers the bulb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are true. The cell produces electrical energy from chemical energy, and this electrical energy flows through the circuit to make the bulb glow. The reason directly explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: A student sets up a circuit: cell → wire → bulb → wire → cell. The bulb does not glow. Which of the following could NOT be the reason?

options.text: The wires are made of copper

questions.explanation_correct: Copper wires are excellent conductors of electricity and would allow current to flow. This could NOT be the reason for the bulb not glowing. A dead cell, fused bulb, or disconnected wire could all prevent the bulb from glowing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A dead cell has no energy. A fused bulb has a broken filament that cannot carry current. A disconnected wire breaks the circuit. But copper wires being used is a good thing — copper is a great conductor and would help the circuit work.

questions.question_text:
Rahul inserted different objects between two terminals in a circuit to test conductivity. The bulb glowed for which of the following objects?
(i) Iron key  (ii) Plastic pen  (iii) Aluminium foil  (iv) Glass bangle
questions.explanation_correct: The iron key and aluminium foil are both made of metals (conductors), so they allow electricity to pass through and the bulb glows. The plastic pen and glass bangle are insulators and do not conduct electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic and glass are insulators and will not allow current to flow. Only metal objects (iron key and aluminium foil) are conductors and will make the bulb glow when placed in the circuit.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about an electric switch is INCORRECT?

options.text: A switch can be used to turn a device on or off
When a switch is ON, the circuit is closed
A switch produces electricity for the circuit
When a switch is OFF, the circuit is open

questions.explanation_correct: A switch does NOT produce electricity. It only controls the flow of electricity by opening or closing the circuit. The cell or battery produces the electricity. The switch just acts as a gate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A switch can turn devices on/off (A is correct). When ON, the circuit is closed (B is correct). When OFF, the circuit is open (D is correct). But a switch does NOT produce electricity (C is incorrect) — it only opens or closes the circuit.

questions.question_text: In a circuit, if you remove the cell but keep all other connections intact, what will happen?

options.text: The bulb will not glow because there is no source of electricity

questions.explanation_correct: The cell is the source of electrical energy in the circuit. Without a cell, there is no source of electricity to push the current through the circuit, so the bulb will not glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wires and switches do not produce electricity — they only carry and control the flow. Without the cell (source of energy), no current flows and the bulb cannot glow.

questions.question_text: Why are handles of electric tools (like screwdrivers used by electricians) made of plastic or rubber?

options.text: Because rubber and plastic are insulators that protect against electric shock

questions.explanation_correct: Plastic and rubber are insulators — they do not conduct electricity. By making the handles from these materials, electricians are protected from electric shock when working with live wires.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While cost and weight may be secondary considerations, the main reason is safety. Insulating handles made of plastic or rubber prevent electric current from passing through the tool to the person using it.

questions.question_text: If a cell is used continuously for a long time, the bulb in the circuit starts to glow dimmer and eventually stops. This is because:

options.text: The chemicals in the cell are getting used up
The bulb is absorbing the cell

questions.explanation_correct: The cell works by converting chemical energy into electrical energy. Over time, the chemicals inside the cell get used up, producing less and less electrical energy. This makes the bulb glow dimmer until the cell is fully drained.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wires do not age that quickly, and the switch and bulb do not cause this issue. The dimming occurs because the chemicals inside the cell are gradually consumed, reducing the energy available.

questions.question_text: A student made a simple switch using two drawing pins and a safety pin on a piece of cardboard. What material property of the safety pin makes it work as a switch?

options.text: It is a conductor of electricity

questions.explanation_correct: The safety pin is made of metal, which is a conductor of electricity. When the safety pin touches both drawing pins, it creates a conducting path that closes the circuit. This is the essential property that makes it work as a switch.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While flexibility helps in moving the pin, the essential property is that it conducts electricity. If it were an insulator (like a plastic clip), touching the drawing pins would not complete the circuit. Being shiny or lightweight is irrelevant.

questions.question_text: A bulb has two terminals. Why is it necessary for both terminals of the bulb to be connected in the circuit?

options.text: To make the bulb look neat
So that current can enter through one terminal and exit through the other, completing the circuit
Only one terminal is actually needed
The second terminal is for safety purposes only

questions.explanation_correct: For current to flow through the bulb's filament and make it glow, current must enter through one terminal and exit through the other. Both terminals must be connected to complete the circuit path through the bulb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One terminal is not enough — current needs a path to flow through. Both terminals must be connected so current enters one, passes through the filament (making it glow), and exits the other.

questions.question_text:
Match the following:
(i) Copper wire – P. Insulator
(ii) Rubber band – Q. Conductor
(iii) Steel spoon – R. Insulator
(iv) Wooden scale – S. Conductor
Which is the correct match?
questions.explanation_correct: Copper wire is a conductor (Q). Rubber band is an insulator (P). Steel spoon is a conductor (S). Wooden scale is an insulator (R). So the correct match is (i)-Q, (ii)-P, (iii)-S, (iv)-R.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metals (copper, steel) are conductors. Non-metals (rubber, wood) are insulators. The correct matching puts conductors with Q and S, and insulators with P and R.

questions.question_text: A student draws a circuit diagram showing a cell connected to a bulb with a switch. In the diagram, the switch is shown in the open position. What does this tell us?

options.text: The circuit is complete and current is flowing
The circuit is incomplete and the bulb is not glowing

questions.explanation_correct: An open switch means the circuit is incomplete (open). In an open circuit, no current flows, so the bulb is not glowing. The diagram shows that the circuit is broken at the switch.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An open switch breaks the circuit. Without a complete path, current cannot flow and the bulb cannot glow. The cell is connected, but the open switch prevents current flow.

questions.question_text: The negative terminal of a dry cell is the flat ___ disc at the bottom.
questions.explanation_correct: The negative terminal of a dry cell is the flat metal disc at the bottom of the cell. The positive terminal is the raised metal cap on top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The flat disc at the bottom of a dry cell is made of metal and serves as the negative terminal.

questions.question_text: In your home, light switches are used to control each room's lights separately. This is useful because:

options.text: All lights must be turned on at the same time
Each switch controls one circuit, allowing you to turn individual lights on or off as needed
Switches generate electricity for each room

questions.explanation_correct: Each switch controls a separate circuit for a particular light or room. This allows you to turn individual lights on or off without affecting others, saving electricity and providing convenience.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Switches do not generate electricity or serve as decorations. They control individual circuits, allowing selective use of electrical devices without turning everything on at once.

questions.question_text: Water is always a good insulator of electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: Pure (distilled) water is a poor conductor, but tap water, river water, and sea water contain dissolved salts that make them good conductors of electricity. So water is not always a good insulator.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. While pure water is a poor conductor, the water we commonly encounter (tap water, sea water) contains dissolved salts and minerals that make it a conductor. Therefore, water is not always a good insulator.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following arrangements will make the bulb glow?
(i) Cell → wire → bulb → wire → back to cell (switch ON)
(ii) Cell → wire → bulb (wire not connected back to cell)
(iii) Cell → wire → switch (OFF) → wire → bulb → wire → back to cell
questions.explanation_correct: Only arrangement (i) has a complete closed circuit with the switch ON, allowing current to flow. Arrangement (ii) is open — the wire does not return to the cell. Arrangement (iii) has the switch OFF, making it an open circuit. Only (i) will make the bulb glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For the bulb to glow, the circuit must be complete (closed). (ii) has no return path. (iii) has the switch OFF (open circuit). Only (i) provides a complete path with the switch ON.

questions.question_text: When connecting cells to form a battery, the correct method is:

options.text: Connect positive terminal to positive terminal of the next cell
Connect negative terminal to negative terminal of the next cell
Connect positive terminal of one cell to negative terminal of the next cell

questions.explanation_correct: To form a working battery, the positive terminal of one cell must be connected to the negative terminal of the next cell. This is called connecting cells in series and ensures that the energy from all cells adds up.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Connecting positive to positive or negative to negative will not produce a working battery. The correct method is to connect the positive terminal of one cell to the negative terminal of the next cell (series connection).

questions.question_text: A student wants to check whether a liquid is a conductor or insulator. She dips two wires (connected to a cell and bulb) into the liquid. If the bulb glows, the liquid is a:
questions.explanation_correct: If the bulb glows when the wires are dipped in the liquid, it means the liquid is allowing electric current to pass through it, completing the circuit. This means the liquid is a conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the bulb glows, current is flowing through the liquid, which means the liquid conducts electricity — it is a conductor. If it were an insulator, the bulb would not glow.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of an open circuit in everyday life?

options.text: A fan running at full speed
A tube light that is switched off

questions.explanation_correct: When a tube light is switched off, the switch breaks the circuit, creating an open circuit. No current flows and the tube light does not glow. This is an everyday example of an open circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A running fan, a charging phone, and a working heater all have closed circuits with current flowing. Only the switched-off tube light has an open circuit where the switch has broken the current path.

questions.question_text: If two bulbs are connected in a circuit and one bulb fuses (breaks), what will happen if they are connected one after the other (in the same path)?

options.text: Both bulbs will continue to glow
Only the fused bulb will stop glowing
Both bulbs will stop glowing because the circuit is broken
The other bulb will glow brighter

questions.explanation_correct: When bulbs are connected one after the other (in series), current must pass through both. If one bulb fuses, the filament breaks, creating a gap in the circuit. This makes the entire circuit open, so both bulbs stop glowing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a series connection, if one bulb fuses, it breaks the entire circuit path. No current can flow at all, so both bulbs stop working, not just the fused one.

questions.question_text: Your body is a conductor of electricity. This is one reason why:

options.text: You should always touch electrical wires
You should never touch bare electrical wires, as you could get an electric shock
You need rubber shoes to walk faster

questions.explanation_correct: The human body contains water and salts, making it a conductor of electricity. If you touch a bare wire carrying current, the current can pass through your body and give you a dangerous electric shock. This is why we must never touch bare electrical wires.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since the body conducts electricity, touching bare wires is dangerous and can cause electric shock or even death. You should never touch bare wires, and wearing rubber-soled shoes is for insulation from ground, not for walking faster.

questions.question_text: Which part of a dry cell is the positive terminal?
questions.explanation_correct: The positive terminal of a dry cell is the metal cap (small bump) on top. The flat metal disc at the bottom is the negative terminal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The flat bottom disc is the negative terminal. The cardboard cover and side are not terminals. The metal cap on top is the positive terminal (+).

questions.question_text: Which sequence correctly describes the flow of current in a simple circuit?

options.text: Positive terminal → wire → bulb → wire → negative terminal
Negative terminal → wire → bulb → wire → positive terminal

questions.explanation_correct: By convention, electric current flows from the positive terminal of the cell through the wire to the bulb, then through the wire back to the negative terminal. This is called conventional current flow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conventional current flows from positive to negative terminal. It does not start from the bulb or switch. The correct path is: positive terminal → wire → bulb → wire → negative terminal.

questions.question_text: When a switch is in the ON position, the circuit is said to be:
questions.explanation_correct: When a switch is ON, it connects the gap in the circuit, making it a closed (complete) circuit. A closed circuit allows electric current to flow through it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An ON switch completes the circuit, making it closed. An open circuit means the path is broken. When the switch is ON, the circuit is closed, allowing current to flow.

questions.question_text: Which of the following everyday objects makes use of the property that certain materials are conductors and certain are insulators?

options.text: An electric plug (metal pins inside, plastic body outside)

questions.explanation_correct: An electric plug uses both conductors and insulators. The metal pins are conductors that carry current. The plastic body is an insulator that protects the user from electric shock. This combination uses both properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A wooden chair, glass of water, and cotton shirt do not specifically use the conductor-insulator combination for electrical purposes. An electric plug is designed with conducting metal pins and an insulating plastic body for safe electricity use.

questions.question_text: A TV remote control uses 2 cells. The cells must be placed in the correct orientation. What happens if one cell is placed in reverse (wrong way)?

options.text: The remote works but in reverse
The remote does not work because the cells cancel each other out

questions.explanation_correct: When one cell is reversed, its positive and negative terminals oppose the other cell. The voltages cancel each other out, and no effective current flows. The remote control will not work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A reversed cell opposes the other cell, cancelling out the electrical energy. The remote will not work normally, in reverse, or become louder — it simply will not function.

questions.question_text: A student has a circuit with a cell, switch, and bulb. She notices the bulb is glowing. She now opens the switch. Which statement is correct?

options.text: The bulb continues to glow because the cell still has energy
The bulb stops glowing immediately because the circuit is now open
The cell stops producing electricity permanently

questions.explanation_correct: When the switch is opened, the circuit is broken (open). No current can flow through an open circuit, so the bulb stops glowing immediately. The cell still has energy but the broken circuit prevents current from reaching the bulb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Even though the cell has energy, the open switch breaks the circuit path. Without a complete path, current cannot flow, and the bulb stops glowing immediately. The cell is not permanently damaged — closing the switch will make the bulb glow again.
